cards.front: What is the resting membrane potential?
cards.back: About −70 mV (inside negative). Maintained by Na⁺/K⁺ pump. Threshold for firing: ~−55 mV. Spike peak: ~+40 mV.
1. Na⁺ channels open → depolarization (−55 → +40 mV). 2. K⁺ channels open → repolarization (+40 → −70 mV). 3. Brief hyperpolarization (~−80 mV). Duration: ~1 ms. All-or-none.

cards.front: What is the Poisson spike model?
cards.back: P(k spikes in t) = (λt)^k · e^(−λt) / k!. Constant rate λ. No voltage dynamics. Memoryless. Used for large population statistics.
Cm·dVm/dt = I(t) − Vm/Rm. Spike when V > Vth, then reset. RC circuit: Cm charges via I(t), leaks via Rm. Workhorse of computational neuroscience.
C·dV/dt = −gNa·m³h·(V−ENa) − gK·n⁴·(V−EK) − gL·(V−EL) + I. Plus 3 gating ODEs for m, n, h. 4th-order nonlinear system.
2D reduction of HH: ε·dV/dt = V − V³/3 − W + I, τ·dW/dt = V + a − bW. Fast activator (V) + slow inhibitor (W). Captures excitability qualitatively.

cards.front: Why is HH described as 'an equivalent circuit'?
cards.back: Membrane = capacitor C. Each ion channel = voltage-dependent conductance (gNa·m³h, gK·n⁴). Reversal potentials = voltage sources. It IS a nonlinear circuit.

cards.front: What does the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model add to pure diffusion?
cards.back: Mean reversion: dV = −(V−μ)/τ dt + σdW. The −(V−μ)/τ term pulls voltage back toward rest with time constant τ, mimicking passive membrane leak.

cards.front: List the 6 neuron model categories in order of increasing fidelity.
cards.back: 1. Random spiking (Poisson). 2. State transition (Markov). 3. Stochastic (OU/diffusion). 4. Integrate-and-Fire (LIF). 5. Reduced HH (FHN, Theta). 6. Bio-realistic (Hodgkin-Huxley).

cards.front: What is the Spike Response Model?
cards.back: Kernel-based: V(t) = Ση(t−tf) + ∫κ(τ)I(t−τ)dτ + Vres. The neuron as a filter — convolves input with kernel κ(τ) plus refractory contributions η from past spikes.
